title-group.article-title: Vertical Slumber, the Hypnoglyph, and the Outs and Ins of the Postmodern

p.mixed-citation:
Farrar, Straus and Giroux, LLC: Excerpt from "The Diary of Helena Morley" from The Collected Prose by Elizabeth Bishop
Farrar
The Collected Prose

Alice Helen Methfessel. "Sleeping Standing Up" from The Complete Poems: 1927-1979 by Elizabeth Bishop
Helen Methfessel
The Complete Poems: 1927-1979

Alice Helen Methfessel. Excerpt from Notebook Entry, late July 1934 by Elizabeth Bishop
Helen Methfessel
Excerpt from Notebook Entry 1934

Borbély's Secrets of Sleep 85-96
Borbély
85 Secrets of Sleep

Postmodern Genres, edited by Marjorie Perloff, who outlines the possible coordinates of such genres (most notably on pages 7-8)
Perloff
7 Postmodern Genres
Lessing's adjective is actually "prägnantesten" or "most pregnant" (158).

Bishop composed and published "Sleeping Standing Up" is ably dis- cussed by Brett C. Millier (86-92 and 144)
Millier
86 Sleeping Standing Up

David Jarraway's remarks concerning the outlandish posture of a mariner who sleeps atop a mast in "The Unbeliever. "Jarraway associates the seafarer's "tightly closed eyes" with resistance to narratives of nonconformist subjectivity (251)

Lorrie Goldensohn presents a related view on the interpretive muddle that Bishop engenders in "Sleeping Standing Up" and other poems dating to the interval in Paris (110-11).
Goldensohn
110 Sleeping Standing Up
Heidegger's argument shifts attention from "the sur- face time suggested by 'chronology,' the ordinary (vulgaär!) conception of time of everyday life, to a more central structure of time" (421)
" And in addition, for such artists, "outer reality becomes emblematic of inner reality" (139)

Schor's The Overworked American (especially 11, 18, 20)
Schor
11 The Overworked American

W.J.T. Mitchell has de- scribed as "a postlinguistic, postsemiotic rediscovery of the picture as a complex interplay between visuality, apparatus, institutions, discourse, bodies, and figurality" (Picture Theory 16)
Mitchell
16 Picture Theory
"extraordinary space through which all the images and icons of the culture spill and float, haphaz- ard, like a logjam of the visual" (175)

Mitchell's locution, the "imagetext," which refers to "composite, synthetic works (or concepts) that combine image and text" (Picture Theory 89n9)
Mitchell
Picture Theory

"Transformations of the Image," where Jameson argues that wholesale visual arrogation, a condition in which "aesthetic attention finds itself transferred to the life of perception as such," is conspicuously postmodern (112)

Jameson, in this regard, has succinctly remarked that "the newer allegorical structures are post- modern and cannot be articulated without the allegory of postmodernism itself" (Postmodernism 169).
Jameson
169 Postmodernism
Desiderio's comment (end of section IV above) on a metaphorical tie-in between sleep and habitual activities
Lavie's The Enchanted World of Sleep
